New Records: Toronto Raptors suffered their worst defeat of their NBA season opener with a 30-point loss to the Cleveland Cavaliers, surpassing their previous record of 29 points set in their 2001 season opener against Orlando.
Key Match Events: Cleveland Cavaliers rallied from a 7-point deficit to take a 33-32 lead, never trailing again; Toronto Raptors led for much of the first quarter but were outscored by 13-5 in the final minutes of the quarter; Cavaliers widened their lead to 69-49 by halftime and to 26 points by the end of the third quarter.
Pre-Game Insights: Toronto Raptors entered the game with an 18-11 record in season openers, having won eight of their last 11; The team started strong, leading for much of the first quarter with an advantage of up to seven points.
Post-Match Reflections: Raptors head coach Darko Rajakovic expressed pride in his team's overall effort and the opportunity for four rookies to make their NBA debuts; He also expressed confidence in Scottie Barnes, saying 'We all believe in Scottie and know what kind of player he is and how he will contribute to the team.'
Miscellaneous Highlights: Guard Immanuel Quickley left the game in the second quarter with a right pelvic injury; Rookie Jamal Shead led the quartet of first-timers with 10 points and four assists; A sold-out crowd of 19,800 fans, including former Raptors players from the past 29 seasons and recently inducted Hall of Famer Vince Carter, filled the Scotiabank Arena.
Others: Scottie Barnes managed just nine points on 3-for-14 shooting and recorded a game-worst minus-33 rating; The 23-year-old had only two games last season with fewer points.
